system: You are a helpful assistant on Ċ.
response: Ċ (minuscule: ċ) is a letter of the Latin alphabet, formed from C with the addition of a dot. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%8A)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ċ.
You are a helpful assistant on Ċ.
response: Ċ is present in the Chechen Latin alphabet, created in the 1990s. The Cyrillic equivalent is ЦӀ, which represents the sound /tsʼ/. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%8A)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ċ.
response: Ċ was formerly used in Irish to represent the lenited form of C. The digraph ch, which is older than ċ in this function in Irish, is now used. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%8A)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ċ.
response: Ċ is the third letter of the Maltese alphabet, preceded by B and followed by D. It represents the voiceless postalveolar affricate [tʃ]. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%8A)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ċ.
response: Ċ is sometimes used in modern scholarly transcripts of Old English to represent [tʃ], to distinguish it from c pronounced as [k], which is otherwise spelled identically. Its voiced equivalent is Ġ. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%8A)
